articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
I am originally from Lima, Peru, but largely grew up in Los Angeles. During my undergraduate education at California State University, Monterey Bay, I was part of the National Science Foundation’s Research Experience for Undergraduates program. I had the opportunity to work with Dr. Steve Litvin & Dr. Jim Barry at the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) documenting the effects of current and future climate change on abalone. I presented the results of my research at conferences such as SACNAS and the Wildlife Society’s Annual Symposium in 2018. I also volunteered with the non-profit organization Return of the Natives, where I was a part of an environmental education program for children and assisted with community planting events aiming restore native dune flora to the Monterey coast. Now, I am working as a research assistant for Dr. Anastasia Quintana, helping with her postdoctoral research on compliance in small-scale fisheries.
Working in the benthic ecology lab. Image: Todd WalshI love being outdoors and exploring local trails with a particular affinity for surveying herptile communities (lizards, snakes, amphibians). My favorite undergraduate field days were the ones where I could interact with native California wildlife and learn about their ecology and relevant conservation efforts. You can always find me in the field looking for cool snakes and lizards! I previously volunteered at the UCSC Fort Ord National Reserve monitoring coastal horned lizard populations to inform the dissertation of Ph.D candidate, Danielle Davis.
Hanging out with a Monterey ensatinaAside from that, I am highly passionate about environmental justice issues and I am an avid supporter of black & indigenous rights. I hope to apply my data analysis skills to serve underprivileged groups.
I currently reside in Goleta, CA (Chumash land) with my pet bunny and partner.
My pet bunny

            I am a master’s student at the Bren School of Environmental Science & Management at UCSB, and I am specializing in Energy & Climate. I am currently working as a research assistant under Dr. Anastasia Quintana, aiding her postdoctoral research at the intersection of small-scale fisheries, conservation, and collective action.

      Larissa Neilson
      Master’s candidate
      

      
      |
       (818) 282-6200 |
      
       eneilson@bren.ucsb.edu |
      
      
      
      

      
      Education
      
      2020-present Master of Environmental Science & Management Bren School of Environmental Science & Management (Santa Barbara, CA)
      
      
      2015-2019 Bachelor of Environmental Science California State University, Monterey Bay (Seaside, CA)
      
      
      
      Research Experience
      
      2020-present Research Assistant University of California, Santa Barbara (Santa Barbara, CA)
      
      Supervisor - Anastasia Quintana
      Duties:
      • Conducting literature reviews to inform postdoctoral research on compliance in small-scale fisheries
      • Identifying governance types in 75+ managed access areas throughout Indonesia, Brazil, Honduras, Micronesia, Mozambique, and the Philippines & creating a dataset with this information
      • Managing the social media presence of Dr. Anastasia Quintana to help expand her network
      
      June - August 2018 Undergraduate Researcher Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (Moss Landing, CA)
      
      Supervisors - Dr. Steve Litvin, Dr. Jim Barry
      • Quantified & analyzed the effects of present & future climate change and ocean acidification associated with upwelling on juvenile Haliotis rufescens (red abalone) through an 8-week live experiment
      • Created & maintained Excel worksheets with abalone measurement parameters for all 300+ individuals
      • Conducted extensive image and statistical analysis using experimental data from 300+ individuals
      • Presented results to audiences ranging from 5-200 people at various conferences and symposiums including SACNAS and the California Central Coast Chapter of The Wildlife Society’s Annual Symposium
      
      
      Volunteer Experience
      
      June - July 2019 Herptile Population Monitoring Volunteer University of California, Santa Cruz Fort Ord Natural Reserve (Marina, CA)
      
      • Surveyed & monitored Phrynosoma blainvillii (Blainville’s horned lizard) populations by catching and PIT tagging individuals
      • Handled live animals & collected data in the field using measurement equipment to capture parameters such as weight and snout-vent length
      • Informed the dissertation of Danielle Davis (UCSC) looking at temporal differences in horned lizard population over time at the UCSC FONR
      
      March - May 2019 Dungeness Crab Population Project Volunteer California State University, Monterey Bay (Seaside, CA)
      
      • Collected megalopa crab population data for a California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) monitoring project aiming to inform Dungeness crab fisheries
      • Gathered & stored megalopa crab samples once a week from a trap at the Moss Landing Marine Labs boat dock
      • Organized & maintained crab sample counts and measurement data into project notebook
      
      January - May 2018 Educational Outreach Volunteer Return of the Natives (Seaside, CA)
      
      • Co-taught an environmental education outreach program for 4th-5th grade elementary classes at local, lower-income schools
      • Prepared & organized lecture material for environmental science presentations adequate for 10-12-year old’s. Topics included photosynthesis, waste management, and climate change
      • Assisted in organizing multiple beach planting community events with the goal of reintroducing 200+ native plants across ~5 species back to vulnerable dune ecosystems
      
      
      Skills and certifications
      Computer: Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint), R, Google Suite, Outlooks
      Language: Bilingual (Spanish), public speaking, problem resolution, team building
      Certifications: CITI Responsible Research & Conduct, Trimble GPS
